Award.AwardTitle: Higher-Order Corrections to Massive Particle Production at the Large Hadron Collider
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Andrea Ferroglia and Giovanni Ossola at the New York City College of Technology of the City University of New York.

The data collected and analyzed by the experimental collaborations at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) allowed physicists to achieve the first main goal of the LHC scientific program, namely the discovery of the Higgs boson. In the near future, the primary goals of the LHC will be to study the properties of the new particle and to search for signals of new phenomena which are not described by the current Standard Model of particle physics. Theorists need to provide precise predictions for the measured observables. Additional theoretical challenges are provided by processes with several particles in the final state and by the presence of massive particles, such as top quarks and Higgs bosons. The PIs are experts in calculations of these complicated processes, which are necessary for fully understanding the properties of the Higgs boson (and any other particles that may be discovered in the next run of the LHC).

The goal of the project is to apply the most advanced technical tools for the calculation of radiative corrections in QCD to processes involving real and/or virtual massive particles, such as Higgs bosons, top-quark pairs, and pairs of colored supersymmetric partners of quarks and gluons. For many observables, calculations which go beyond the currently available accuracy are necessary. The PI's plan to employ and further develop the GoSam framework for one-loop calculations, effective field theory methods which allow them to carry out the resummation of large logarithmic corrections directly in momentum space, and recently introduced methods for the analytic or numerical calculation of multiloop and multileg Feynman diagrams.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project “Higher-Order Corrections to Massive Particle Production at the Large Hadron Collider” was devoted to the study of high-precision theoretical predictions for particle collisions involving the production of massive Standard Model particles, such as the top quark, the W and Z vector bosons, and the Higgs bosons. The comparison of these results with the experimental data coming from particle colliders, such as the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, could lead to a further validation of the present model and the detection of hints of disagreements between theory and experiment which would lead to new models for the interaction between fundamental particles.

We list below a selection of the specific processes that we studied within the span of this NSF award. Each of these results was accompanied by the development of new computational tools needed to cope with the complexity of each specific calculations. A considerable portion of our work was indeed devoted to the development of new computational techniques, more refined codes, or interfaces between existing codes to automate lengthy portion of the calculations. The benefits provided by these general technical developments go beyond the specific needs of the individual calculations.

A significant portion of the work supported by this grant dealt with the production of top-quark pairs. The top quark is the heaviest fundamental particle in the current Standard Model of Particle Physics, and also the particle that couples most strongly with the Higgs boson. For these reasons, processes involving the production of top quarks are expected to play a key role in the study of the electroweak symmetry breaking sector of the Standard Model.

In particular, the corrections stemming from the emission of soft gluons in the final state were resummed up to next-to-next-to-leading logarithmic accuracy. Resummed predictions for the total cross section and several differential distributions were then matched to calculations including next-to-leading order QCD and electroweak corrections.

In addition, for the top-pair production, an analysis of the logarithms that become singular in the limit of vanishing top-quark mass was carried out.

In all of the cases listed above, the resummation of the soft-emission corrections was carried out by means of soft-collinear effective field theory methods. Several technical problems had to be solved in order to obtain these expressions. In particular, the process-dependent hard functions had to be evaluated numerically. An in-house Monte Carlo code for the numerical evaluation was developed.

In a different project, we studied the productions of a top pair and a Higgs boson and compared it with its background process in which a pair of photons are produced instead of the Higgs boson, matched to a parton shower. In the phenomenological analyses of these processes, we focused on observables sensitive to the polarization of the top quarks, such as angular variables.
In addition, the effect of the possible presence of a pseudo-scalar component in the coupling between the top-quark and the Higgs boson was studied. Observables sensitive to the scalar or pseudoscalar nature of the Higgs-top quark coupling were identified.

As a different project, within the support of this grant, we took part in a high-precision study of the corrections to the radiative decay of the B meson. The study involved several authors that in the recent pasts contributed to the calculation of elements needed for the evaluation of this process at next-to-next-to-leading order accuracy. This collaboration led to the publication of an updated estimate of the branching ratio for this process, which plays a crucial role in setting bounds on new physics model.

Overall, this NSF grant allowed us to study and obtain high-precision predictions for a wide selection of processes involving the production of top-quark pairs, with and without the associated production of a heavy boson. These predictions are ready to be compared with the data coming from the experimental collaborations at the Large Hadron Collider, and will be extremely useful in further supporting the present understanding of the interactions between fundamental particles, as described by the Standard Model, or in detecting hints of disagreement which would lead new more sophisticated theoretical models and ultimately a deeper understanding of the fundamental building blocks of our Universe.

Within the time span of this grant, several students have been involved in various research projects at different levels of complexity, from introductory projects for non-science students to more advanced projects for students within the physics major in applied computational physics. The grant also supported the work of two graduate students, who earned their doctoral degrees in 2016 and 2019, respectively. Several speakers and collaborators were invited to our Institution to present the  results of their research and to interact with our faculty and students.
